p: Our study showed that 13 Aedes species eggs were maintained in the different land covers and breeding sites sampled in southeastern Senegal. This diversity is greater than that observed in a previous study conducted in the same area with only 9 Aedes species emerged from eggs samples collected in tree holes [ 23]. The higher number of breeding sites and land cover classes investigated in our study would explain this difference. Indeed, Diallo and others [ 23] only surveyed tree holes from a single forest gallery while our study covered 4 types of breeding sites in 5 different land cover classes. However, 12 Aedes species previously found as larvae [ 24] or adults [ 27] in this area were not found in this study. This could be explained by the inaccessibility of tree holes located at height higher than 2â€‰m, which may be preferential habitat for these arboreal species. Indeed, variations of breeding behavior of some mosquito species depending on tree height were observed by some authors [ 34, 35]. The entrances of these tree holes may also be hidden by their small sizes or their location behind tree barks. Despite the fact that we were interested to the eggs (that are not mobile), sampling in different months and years could be considered as a limitation in our study.
